channel.title: NYT > Business
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tesla to Investigate Car That Appeared to Burst Into Flames in Shanghai
item.media:description: In January Tesla started construction on a huge new factory near Shanghai, its first plant outside the United States.
item.description: The fire, involving a Tesla sedan in a parking garage, left no one injured, the fire department said. The automaker said it had dispatched a team “at once.”
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: Japanese Prosecutors Bring New Charge Against Carlos Ghosn
item.media:description: Carlos Ghosn, the former Nissan chairman, leaving his lawyer’s office in Tokyo on April 3. He was arrested the next day, his fourth arrest so far.
item.description: Mr. Ghosn, the former head of the Nissan-Renault auto alliance, was formally charged with breach of trust, adding a new count of financial impropriety onto his existing three charges.
item.dc:creator: BEN DOOLEY

item.title: White Collar Watch: Elizabeth Warren Wants to Make It Easier to Prosecute Executives
item.media:description: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts at a campaign stop in New Hampshire last month.
item.media:credit: John Tully for The New York Times
item.description: The key question is whether the legislation she has proposed is the best means to police corporate leaders.
item.dc:creator: PETER J. HENNING

item.title: It’s U.S. vs. World as Big Tech Faces Specter of Limiting Speech Online
item.description: Many other countries are adopting or considering stricter moderation of online speech. But they don’t have to work around the First Amendment.
item.dc:creator: CECILIA KANG

item.title: Trump’s Washing Machine Tariffs Stung Consumers While Lifting Corporate Profits
item.media:description: Companies raised both washer and dryer prices last year, by 11.5 percent each, a new study says. Only washers were subject to President Trump's tariffs.
item.description: New research shows how a move meant to aid domestic manufacturers instead padded profits and raised prices on a wide variety of laundry items.
item.dc:creator: JIM TANKERSLEY

item.title: Claims of Shoddy Production Draw Scrutiny to a Second Boeing Jet
item.media:description: New 787 Dreamliners at the Boeing plant in North Charleston, S.C. When unveiled in 2007, the Dreamliner was Boeing’s most important new plane in a generation and an immediate hit with carriers.
item.description: Workers at a 787 Dreamliner plant in South Carolina have complained of defective manufacturing, debris left on planes and pressure to not report violations.
item.dc:creator: NATALIE KITROEFF and DAVID GELLES
item.category: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

item.title: Hospitals Stand to Lose Billions Under ‘Medicare for All’
item.media:description: Proponents held up signs as Senator Bernie Sanders introduced the Medicare for All bill in Washington this month.
item.description: Private insurance pays hospitals much more than the federal government does for patient care. If Medicare for all means Medicare rates, expect an industry backlash.
item.dc:creator: REED ABELSON

item.title: Zoom Video’s Stock Soared in Public Debut. So Did Zoom Technologies’.
item.media:description: The opening of trading in Zoom Video Communications last Thursday. Its shares soared more than 72 percent that day.
item.description: Twitter, Tweeter. Nest, Nestor. Sometimes, shares in similarly named companies get caught up in the excitement of a deal or I.P.O.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN GROCER

item.title: Silicon Valley Came to Kansas Schools. That Started a Rebellion.
item.media:description: A yard sign in Wellington, Kan., where some parents and students have rebelled against a web-based education program from Summit Learning.
item.media:credit: Christopher Smith for The New York Times
item.description: Public schools in Kansas rolled out a web-based learning platform backed by Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg. Now students have staged walkouts and sit-ins. Their parents have organized.
item.dc:creator: NELLIE BOWLES

item.title: Google Employees Say They Faced Retaliation After Organizing Walkout
item.media:description: A Google employee protest in November in San Francisco. Two workers who called for a walkout over Google’s treatment of sexual harassment said they had been demoted or told that their role would change.
item.description: Two Google workers who called for an employee protest over the company’s treatment of sexual harassment said they were demoted or told their role would change.
item.dc:creator: KATE CONGER and DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: A Vicious, Untreatable Killer Leaves China Guessing
item.media:description: The Wangaofa Animal Husbandry Development Company had to cull thousands of pigs this year after an outbreak of African swine fever. The facility now sits empty, its hallways splattered white with disinfecting lime.
item.description: African swine fever, which harms pigs but not humans, has swept across the country, the world’s largest pork producer. And those are only the cases the government knows about.
item.dc:creator: RAYMOND ZHONG and AILIN TANG

item.title: Trump Will Not Nominate Herman Cain to Fed Board
item.media:description: Herman Cain has withdrawn from consideration to be nominated to the Federal Reserve Board.
item.description: Facing bipartisan opposition in the Senate, former pizza executive and presidential candidate Herman Cain withdraws from consideration for the Federal Reserve.
item.dc:creator: JIM TANKERSLEY and ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: Stop & Shop Strike Ends With Union Claiming Victory on Pay and Health Care
item.media:description: The union representing Stop & Shop workers said in a statement that the tentative deal reached on Sunday “preserves health care and retirement benefits, provides wage increases, and maintains time-and-a-half pay on Sunday for current members.”
item.description: More than 30,000 cashiers, bakers and other supermarket workers had been on strike for 11 days across three states in New England.
item.dc:creator: SANDRA E. GARCIA
item.category: United Food and Commercial Workers Union

item.title: More Benches, Special Goggles: Taking Steps to Assist Older Travelers
item.media:description: Samantha Flores, the director for experiential design for the architecture firm Corgan, wearing an age-simulation suit at Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport.
item.media:credit: Cassidy Araiza for The New York Times
item.description: The number of people 60 and over is growing. So airports and hotels are beginning to look at design changes to help them.
item.dc:creator: JULIE WEED

item.title: Kraft Heinz Picks New C.E.O. as It Faces Weak Sales and S.E.C. Inquiry
item.media:description: Miguel Patricio will take the helm at Kraft Heinz after spending two decades at Anheuser-Busch, most recently as the brewer’s global chief marketing officer.
item.description: The food giant said Miguel Patricio, an Anheuser-Busch InBev veteran, would succeed Bernardo Hees as chief executive, signaling a potential shift away from years of cost-cutting.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Moves to Stop All Nations From Buying Iranian Oil
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said the United States would no longer grant oil waivers to China and India, Iran’s two largest customers.
item.description: Oil prices rose to their highest levels since October in anticipation of Monday’s announcement by Secretary of State Mike Pompeo. Trump administration officials had debated the move.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: DealBook Briefing: Tesla Wants You to Focus on Its Robo-Taxis (not Its Finances)
item.media:description: Elon Musk
item.description: The electric-car maker plans to show off its latest self-driving vehicle technology, two days before it is expected to announce another quarterly loss.

item.title: Like a Boss: Jonny Sun’s Work Diary: Correct Spellign Optoinal, Creativity Mandatory
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Lippman for The New York Times
item.description: The author-illustrator behind ‘everyone’s a aliebn when ur a aliebn too’ is writing for TV and film, plus pursuing a Ph.D. at M.I.T.
item.dc:creator: LEIGH-ANN JACKSON
item.category: Everyone's a Aliebn When Ur a Aliebn Too (Book)

item.title: The Giants at the Heart of the Opioid Crisis
item.media:description: The headquarters of McKesson Corporation, the drug distributing giant, in San Francisco.
item.media:credit: Anastasiia Sapon for The New York Times
item.description: Civil suits filed by three states accuse pharmaceutical distributors of flooding the country with opioids while devising systems to evade regulators.
item.dc:creator: DANNY HAKIM, WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and RONI CARYN RABIN

item.title: He Stopped a Global Cyberattack. Now He’s Pleading Guilty to Writing Malware.
item.media:description: Marcus Hutchins, right, a British security researcher, at the Federal Courthouse in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, in 2017. He was arrested at the airport in Las Vegas earlier that year.
item.description: Marcus Hutchins, a British security researcher credited with halting a huge outbreak of ransom software in 2017, accepted United States charges over previous activity.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: India Elections 2019: Farmers Are Hurting and Millions Are Voting
item.media:description: An onion market in Lasalgaon, near Nashik, India.
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.description: The ruling B.J.P. party has not yet delivered the “good days” it promised to farm voters, who make up half of the electorate. In debt and despair, some wonder if anyone can.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL and HARI KUMAR

item.title: How Luxury Developers Use a Loophole to Build Soaring Towers for the Ultrarich in N.Y.
item.media:description: About one-fourth of the 88 floors at 432 Park Avenue, one of the world’s tallest residential buildings, have no homes. Instead, they are reserved for structural and mechanical equipment.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: The spread of these buildings overlooking Central Park is provoking a backlash amid a broader debate about affordable housing, extravagant projects and the city’s identity.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW HAAG
item.category: Real Estate Board of New York

item.title: Tesla to Shrink Board of Directors by Four People
item.description: The move, which will reduce the number of directors to seven, is meant to improve corporate governance of the electric car company.
item.dc:creator: NEAL E. BOUDETTE

item.title: Ancestry.com Apologizes for Ad Showing Slavery-Era Interracial Couple
item.description: The genealogy company said it had pulled a video ad that depicted an interracial couple fleeing the antebellum South.
item.dc:creator: LAURA M. HOLSON

item.title: Before Fisher-Price’s Rock ’n Play Recall, Safety Fears and Dubious Marketing
item.media:description: Fisher-Price issued a recall for its Rock ’n Play sleeper this month after it was linked to multiple infant deaths.
item.media:credit: Consumer Product Safety Commission, via Associated Press
item.description: The company knew for years about potential risks linked to its popular sleeper and about pediatricians’ objections to the way the product was being pitched to parents.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY HSU

item.title: Betting on the Royal Baby
item.media:description: Commemorative items available for purchase by fans of the baby expected by Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan Markle, include mugs; a teabag coaster, center; and a tin of baby biscuits.
item.media:credit: Ben Quinton for The New York Times
item.description: In Britain’s celebrity pregnancy economy, Meghan Markle’s unborn child is inspiring wagers, luxury cookie tins and diamond-encrusted jars of diaper rash cream.
item.dc:creator: TIFFANY HSU and AMIE TSANG

item.title: Strategies: ‘Medicare for All’ Is Hammering Health Care Stocks. For Now.
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders at a Fox News Town Hall on April 15. Mr. Sanders has been a prominent supporter of a “Medicare for All” health insurance program.
item.description: The popularity of proposals for a government-run, single-payer system among Democratic presidential candidates has hurt health care stocks, despite their strong earnings.
item.dc:creator: JEFF SOMMER

item.title: Half of England Is Owned by Less Than 1% of Its Population, Researcher Says
item.media:description: Farm workers in the fields near Boston, Lincolnshire, England.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: A new book identifies aristocrats, investors and companies that own vast portions of the country, amid growing complaints about land scarcity and economic inequality.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Commuting While Pregnant: A Long Ride Could Be a Risky One
item.description: Traveling 50 or more miles to and from work may negatively affect unborn babies, a new study suggests.
item.dc:creator: MAYA SALAM

item.title: Are You a Very English Butler? The U.K. Government Needs You
item.media:description: Grant Harrold was once a butler to Prince Charles. “The reality of a modern-day butler is that it is evolving into this hospitality role,” he said.
item.media:credit: Susie Mackie/REX, via EPA, via Shutterstock
item.description: The Foreign Office has advertised for two butlers responsible for delivering “V.I.P. hospitality” and managing a wine cellar. Maximum annual salary: £30,000.
item.dc:creator: ANNA SCHAVERIEN

item.title: DealBook: Socialist! Capitalist! Economic Systems as Weapons in a War of Words
item.media:description: It wouldn’t be surprising if a proposal in Joseph Stiglitz's new book became the economic platform for a presidential candidate.
item.media:credit: Stephanie Mei-Ling for The New York Times
item.description: The economist Joseph Stiglitz discusses Bernie Sanders, social policy and how we define ourselves — and one another.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW ROSS SORKIN

item.title: Merger Talks of Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank Roil Emotions
item.media:description: A merger of Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank would leave Germany with only one large publicly traded bank, compared with at least four a decade ago.
item.description: A proposed deal is meeting resistance from labor, regulators and some shareholders. But there is also political momentum in Germany for a tie-up.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Work Friend: The Wages of Being a Woman at Work
item.media:credit: Emily Simms for The New York Times
item.description: Let’s just say they’re a little low.
item.dc:creator: KATY LEDERER

item.title: After Social Media Bans, Militant Groups Found Ways to Remain
item.media:description: Hezbollah has been barred by the big social media companies. But the Islamist militant group has found a way to stay a step ahead online.
item.description: Hezbollah and other groups classified as terrorist organizations by the United States have changed their social media strategies to stay on Facebook, YouTube and Twitter.
item.dc:creator: SHEERA FRENKEL and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: The Real Stars of the Internet
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times
item.description: The rater has become the rated.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HERRMAN

item.title: Tesla and Elon Musk Are Given Week to Reach Accord With S.E.C.
item.media:description: Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, arriving at a federal courthouse in New York for a hearing this month. The Securities and Exchange Commission sought a contempt citation, saying he had violated a settlement over his disclosure of financial information.
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.description: The adversaries told a judge they were working to resolve a dispute over Mr. Musk’s statements on financial prospects. Regulators had sought a contempt citation.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Senator McConnell, a Tobacco Ally, Supports Raising Age to Buy Cigarettes
item.media:description: Leading lawmakers are gathering support for legislation at the federal and state levels to curtail sales of tobacco and vaping products to young adults.
item.description: Seeking re-election to a seventh term, the senator cited the rise in teenage vaping as a reason to curtail sales of tobacco and other products.
item.dc:creator: SHEILA KAPLAN

item.title: The Mueller Show: TV Hosts Unpack 448 Pages in Real Time
item.media:description: Journalists received their copies of the Mueller report — all 448 pages — at the same time as the general public.
item.description: What was billed as a series finale turned out to be more of a midseason cliffhanger.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM

item.title: Trump’s Nafta Revisions Offer Modest Economic Benefits, Report Finds
item.media:description: An Audi assembly line in San José Chilapa, Mexico. The revised regional trade accord would increase the percentage of a vehicle that needs to be made in North America for it to be tariff-free.
item.description: A government study challenges the president’s claims that the proposed North American trade pact makes far-reaching changes to the 1994 agreement.
item.dc:creator: ANA SWANSON

item.title: National Enquirer to Be Sold to James Cohen, Heir to Hudson News Founder
item.media:description: The National Enquirer’s publisher, American Media Inc., had been in talks with several potential buyers for the title.
item.description: A new buyer for the tabloid swooped in after talks between its publisher, American Media, and the billionaire Ron Burkle fell apart.
item.dc:creator: EDMUND LEE

item.title: The Mueller Report’s Free, but Publishers Are Selling It as a Book
item.media:description: Attorney General William P. Barr at a news conference on Thursday, discussing the report by the special counsel, Robert S. Mueller III.
item.description: A number of book publishers are selling the report, released on Thursday, even though it can be read for free online.
item.dc:creator: LAURA M. HOLSON
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: Battle for .amazon Domain Pits Retailer Against South American Nations
item.media:description: Sunrise over the Amazon rainforest in Brazil. Countries that straddle the forest are disputing with the giant online retailer the rights to the domain name .amazon.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: A years-long battle over control of the domain name, which included promises of free Kindles, may soon be decided.
item.dc:creator: SHASTA DARLINGTON
item.category: Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers

item.title: Blackstone Will Ditch Partnership Structure to Draw More Investors
item.description: It is the latest major investment firm to convert to a standard corporation since tax code changes made such a move more enticing.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Corner Office: David Miliband of the International Rescue Committee: ‘The Devil Can’t Have the Best Tunes’
item.media:description: David Miliband, President and CEO of the International Rescue Committee, photographed at the IRC offices in Manhattan
item.media:credit: Guerin Blask for The New York Times
item.description: The son of World War II refugees, Mr. Miliband walked away from British politics. Today he works to bring food, aid and education to refugees around the world.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GELLES

item.title: Here’s Soylent’s New Product. It’s Food.
item.media:description: The three varietals of Soylent Squared.
item.description: The Silicon Valley food-drink of choice is now a ‘complete nutrition platform.’ The beverage plot thickens.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH and JOHN HERRMAN

item.title: I.P.O. Day for Pinterest and Zoom Ends With Shares Sharply Higher
item.media:description: Pinterest’s initial public offering on Thursday was a sign that investor demand for highly anticipated “unicorn” companies remains healthy.
item.description: Coming into these I.P.O.s, there were many questions about whether investors were willing to swallow the risk of the latest crop of tech companies.
item.dc:creator: ERIN GRIFFITH

item.title: DealBook Briefing: Business Heads Back to Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the de facto ruler of Saudi Arabia.
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.description: Six months on from the Jamal Khashoggi tragedy, the international business community is revving up its work with the Arab kingdom.

item.title: Meanwhile: Forget the Easter Bunny. Let’s Celebrate the Easter Bug.
item.description: It takes the goop of hundeds of thousands of lac bugs to create the coating on your favorite shiny candy.
item.dc:creator: WENDY MACNAUGHTON
